%0 Report
%T Freely orientable microstructures for designing deformable 3D prints
%+ Matter from Graphics (MFX)
%+ Models and Algorithms for Visualization and Rendering (MAVERICK)
%A Tricard, Thibault
%A Tavernier, Vincent
%A Zanni, Cédric
%A Martínez, Jonàs
%A Hugron, Pierre-Alexandre
%A Neyret, Fabrice
%A Lefebvre, Sylvain
%I Université de Lorraine, CNRS, Inria, LORIA
%I Université Grenoble Alpes, CNRS, Laboratoire Jean Kuntzmann, Inria
%8 2020-03-30
%D 2020
%Z Computer Science [cs]/Computational Geometry [cs.CG]Reports
%X Nature offers a marvel of astonishing and rich deformation behaviors. Yet, most of the objects we fabricate are comparatively rather inexpressive, either rigid or having simple homogeneous behaviors when interacted with. In this work, we focus on controlling how a 3D printed volume reacts under large deformations. We propose a novel microstructure that is extremely rigid along a transverse direction, while being comparatively very flexible in the orthogonal plane. By allowing free gradation of orientation within the object, the microstructure can be designed such that, under deformation, some distances in the volume are preserved while others freely change. This allows to control the way the volume reshapes when deformed, and results in a wide range of design possibilities. Other gradations are possible, such as locally and progressively canceling the directional effect.To synthesize the structures we propose an algorithm that builds upon procedural texturing. It produces a cellular geometry that can be fabricated reliably despite 3D printing walls at a minimal thickness, for maximal flexibility. The synthesis algorithm is efficient, and scales to large volumes.
%G English
%2 https://hal.inria.fr/hal-02524371v2/document
%2 https://hal.inria.fr/hal-02524371v2/file/FreelyOrientable.pdf

en_title_s: Freely orientable microstructures for designing deformable 3D prints
title_s: Freely orientable microstructures for designing deformable 3D prints
abstract_s: Nature offers a marvel of astonishing and rich deformation behaviors. Yet, most of the objects we fabricate are comparatively rather inexpressive, either rigid or having simple homogeneous behaviors when interacted with. In this work, we focus on controlling how a 3D printed volume reacts under large deformations. We propose a novel microstructure that is extremely rigid along a transverse direction, while being comparatively very flexible in the orthogonal plane. By allowing free gradation of orientation within the object, the microstructure can be designed such that, under deformation, some distances in the volume are preserved while others freely change. This allows to control the way the volume reshapes when deformed, and results in a wide range of design possibilities. Other gradations are possible, such as locally and progressively canceling the directional effect. To synthesize the structures we propose an algorithm that builds upon procedural texturing. It produces a cellular geometry that can be fabricated reliably despite 3D printing walls at a minimal thickness, for maximal flexibility. The synthesis algorithm is efficient, and scales to large volumes.
en_abstract_s: Nature offers a marvel of astonishing and rich deformation behaviors. Yet, most of the objects we fabricate are comparatively rather inexpressive, either rigid or having simple homogeneous behaviors when interacted with. In this work, we focus on controlling how a 3D printed volume reacts under large deformations. We propose a novel microstructure that is extremely rigid along a transverse direction, while being comparatively very flexible in the orthogonal plane. By allowing free gradation of orientation within the object, the microstructure can be designed such that, under deformation, some distances in the volume are preserved while others freely change. This allows to control the way the volume reshapes when deformed, and results in a wide range of design possibilities. Other gradations are possible, such as locally and progressively canceling the directional effect. To synthesize the structures we propose an algorithm that builds upon procedural texturing. It produces a cellular geometry that can be fabricated reliably despite 3D printing walls at a minimal thickness, for maximal flexibility. The synthesis algorithm is efficient, and scales to large volumes.

Université Grenoble Alpes, CNRS, Laboratoire Jean Kuntzmann, Inria. 2020 [Research Report] Université de Lorraine, CNRS, Inria, LORIA; Université Grenoble Alpes, CNRS, Laboratoire Jean Kuntzmann, Inria. 2020 LARA Research Report Freely orientable microstructures for designing deformable 3D prints Thibault Tricard fc6d2f251842d496ec80dbe91d9db755 inria.fr thibault-tricard 176311 44674-176311 Vincent Tavernier 9af82af4f47008b75d2501046d371f85 inria.fr vincent-tavernier 742166 42291-742166 Cédric Zanni 95d2f99d0bae9f6bf94512f22086f3cb loria.fr cedric-zanni 19462 40253-19462 Jonàs Martínez 522beb34f85c44e7e34b0f98fbb0d049 inria.fr jonas-martinez-bayona 6310 28032-6310 https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8443-9624 https://www.idref.fr/262757109 Pierre-Alexandre Hugron 247fa17448cca5b6d699dc059ede8650 inria.fr 1067156 1814273-1067156 Fabrice Neyret 1291441a2221e6238a2fcb661b4da49f inria.fr fabrice-neyret 20288 25095-20288 https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0777-2401 https://www.idref.fr/057467021 Sylvain Lefebvre 137944-0 2020-03-30 Université de Lorraine, CNRS, Inria, LORIA Université Grenoble Alpes, CNRS, Laboratoire Jean Kuntzmann, Inria https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RBQ4y6VGQO8 English Computer Science [cs]/Computational Geometry [cs.CG] Reports

Nature offers a marvel of astonishing and rich deformation behaviors. Yet, most of the objects we fabricate are comparatively rather inexpressive, either rigid or having simple homogeneous behaviors when interacted with. In this work, we focus on controlling how a 3D printed volume reacts under large deformations. We propose a novel microstructure that is extremely rigid along a transverse direction, while being comparatively very flexible in the orthogonal plane. By allowing free gradation of orientation within the object, the microstructure can be designed such that, under deformation, some distances in the volume are preserved while others freely change. This allows to control the way the volume reshapes when deformed, and results in a wide range of design possibilities. Other gradations are possible, such as locally and progressively canceling the directional effect.To synthesize the structures we propose an algorithm that builds upon procedural texturing. It produces a cellular geometry that can be fabricated reliably despite 3D printing walls at a minimal thickness, for maximal flexibility. The synthesis algorithm is efficient, and scales to large volumes.
